1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Once Ashley, Joey, and their families left, it was time for Jason's and my third date. We decided to spend it at home,rather than search for another place that accommodated giants. Netflix and the Jumbotron were a winning combination.

Halfway through the movie, I hinted to Jason that I might be looking for a little more from him than a kiss goodnight at the end of the movie. He, in turn, hinted that he might be interested in that, as well.

Once the movie was over, between kisses, I turned off the TV, and began switching off the lights. Jason took care of the table lamps.

With the lights off, we made our way to the bedroom. There, we kissed some more, then began exploring each other's bodies.

When the moment was right, we made love.

It was nothing like it was with Kyle Dennis back at Old Town Road. Back then, I was a naive little thing, easily led astray by a player who knew the right words, but not the right actions. Jason, on the other hand, let me know that he loved me, just as I let him know I loved him, too. With Kyle Dennis, it was sex. With Jason, it was an act of love.

And, because it was an act of love, I treated Jason with care as he experienced his first sexually-triggered growth spurt.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Our Third Date, and the Next Level

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
My family came over the next morning, while I was having breakfast. Nothing remarkable about that. The thing was, Jason was having breakfast with me.

"Did we come at a bad time?" Mom asked.

"Not at all," I replied. "Sorry I didn't make anything for you guys, but I didn't know you were coming so early. You all know Jason."

"Hello again," he said.

Dad cleared his throat. "Summer," he asked, "are you sure you wanted to do this? I mean, you've been hurt before."

"This is different, Dad." I mean, how obvious did the difference need to be? Kyle Dennis did the exact opposite of staying for breakfast, after all.

"I just don't want to see my little girl's heart get broken again."

"And you won't, Jerry," Mom assured him. "Summer and Jason love each other."

"How can you be sure of that?"

"Son," Grandma said, "if you can't see love on the faces of giants, maybe you'd better let Annette have the keys from now on."

Dad looked at us again, and blushed. "Forgive me," he said. "I love you, and I'm happy for you. I guess I got a little overprotective."

"There's nothing to forgive, Dad," I assured him. "Just remind yourself, I'm a big girl now."

We all laughed, Dad included. "No matter how big you are," he said, "I'll always see the little girl who I taught how to ride a bike. When you're a parent, you'll understand."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: The Family Comes By the Next Morning

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Jason stopped growing at 40 feet tall. Neither one of us minded: he grew up in a house where his mother was taller than his father, and I considered him plenty big enough for my purposes.

"How serious are you two about each other?" Mom asked.

"Plenty serious," I replied. "We're discussing him moving in."

"And getting married?" Dad asked.

"They don't build churches our size, Dad. Where are we supposed to go?"

"A church may be out of the question," Grandpa said, "but there are plenty of places that are big enough for assorted giants. My brothers were married in Sequoia National Forest."

"I've been to weddings at Garden of the Gods in Colorado," Jason said.

"I don't know," I said. "I never much liked the idea of a wedding at a tourist attraction."

"Well, give it some thought, Summer," Grandma said. "The right place for you is out there, just like the right house, the right job, and the right man were."

"I've always trusted you, Grandma," I said, "and you've never steered me wrong. Okay, I will consider different wedding venues. But I'll warn you, Dad: Jason's family can be a bit... much."

"How bad can it be?" Dad asked.

"He's 75 feet tall, she's 100 feet tall, and they're both naked as jaybirds."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Planning for the Future

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Back at work, and another case of a driver who either underestimated how dangerous Old Town Road was, or overestimated his own driving skills. Once he was taken care of, I fell into a conversation with Officer Allison Hayes, a policewoman who often responded to these calls as well. "You've saved another one," she said. "Don't think they haven't noticed you downtown."

"I'm not doing this for accolades," I replied. "I need to earn some money, and I want to help people."

Officer Hayes changed the subject. "How are things going with you and your guy?" she asked.

"We're talking about living together," I replied. "My parents think we should get married. I told them, I've seen the movie where a woman like me is in a church, and it doesn't end well for the church."

"How about Mammoth Stadium?" Mammoth Stadium was the athletic home for West Valley University and its teams, the Titans. It had been my safety school, before I grew too big to fit in.

"Interesting," I said. "But how would I go about reserving it?"

"Remember what I said about downtown. I'm sure that, if you said you'd appreciate it, some arrangement could be made."

It was certainly something to think about.

******************************


Back at home, Jason was there, as usual. "How was work?" he asked.

"Like it usually is," I replied, as I started supper. "I heard about another possible wedding venue."

"Aren't we rushing things?"

"What do you mean?"

"I mean, isn't there something we ought to do before we decide where the wedding will be?"

I turned around to ask what he meant, and I saw him.

He was on one knee, with a ring in his hand.

"Summer Roberts, will you marry me?"

Yeppers, that was definitely something to take care of before we arranged a venue. And so was this: "Yes."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: A Solution Is Found

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
The dean at West Valley U graciously offered to show us around the stadium when we asked. Apparently, one of the people I had helped was one of his children. (I don't mean the student body, I mean his biological offspring.) We entered through the equipment gate. It wouldn't be the most dignified way to enter while dressed to get married, but there we are.

From my perspective as a giant, Mammoth Stadium was both immense and intimate. Yes, it can seat thousands, and has many times. But I was just shy of 17 yards tall, and Jason was just over 13 yards tall, so you know how the playing field looked to us.

"It looks ideal for us," Jason said. "And, with a summer wedding, we won't be interfering with your activities. What do you think, honey?"

"I think I'm in love," I replied. "I'm glad we came here."

"So," Jason said, "let's talk about cost."

"Not an issue," the dean said. "Consider it a wedding gift. Or an early birthday gift, if you like."

"More like belated," I replied. "I'll be 18 before the week is over."

"Congratulations," the dean said. "So it's settled?"

"I believe so. Thank you." I offered my index finger, and we shook on it.

As we were leaving, a garbage truck arrived. "Fancy meeting you here," the driver said.

"Huh?"

The driver stepped out.

It was Kyle Dennis.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Arrangements

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"Hello, Kyle," I said. "This is my fiance, Jason Finnegan. Honey, this is Kyle Dennis, my first."

"How are you, Kyle?"

"Never better," Kyle replied. "I'm in a much better place now."

"What's that supposed to mean?" I asked.

"It means I was in a bad place when I was seeing you. I tried to punish you, and that was the wrong thing to do. I'm sorry, Summer."

I crouched down. "Sounds like I'm not the only one who experienced personal growth after that."

He nodded. "My therapist has done wonders for me. It wasn't my idea, but it's what I needed. And I owe it to you."

"Me? How did I get you into therapy?"

"I tried to talk my family out of it, and they agreed that I wouldn't have to go if you forgave me. Only, in my head, that got turned into me forgiving you. But you showed me where I stood - and where I didn't stand. I was so scared, I practically ran to the therapist's office. Thank you, Summer. I promise, I'll be a much better boyfriend for the next girl."

I smiled. "That's good to hear, Kyle. I'm glad you're getting back on track."

"Thank you. And congratulations." Turning to Jason, he said, "You're a lucky man. Treat her like you know it."

"I've got that covered," Jason said with a grin.

With one more wave, Kyle drove away.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Kyle

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
For my 18th birthday, we all gathered on one of the airstrips and threw a party. Work had just finished on a playground Grandpa had put in, since Ashley and Joey (and who knows how many children in the future) came over so often, so the kids could entertain themselves. "And I was wowing them with my dance moves" is what I would say if I was a great dancer, which I'm not, but I love to dance anyway.

At one point during the party, Jason and I slipped away so we could do some celebrating of our own. You know, the kind of celebrating done with not a lot of people, and even fewer clothes. Yeah, that's right.

Anywho, we were mid-afterglow when a couple of people cleared their throats. Two teenagers, a boy and a girl, with the girl being taller and older.

As we frantically covered ourselves, I managed to ask, "Can we help you with something?"

"Uh, yeah," the boy said. "I, uh, I'm looking for Sam Roberts? I was told she'd be here?"

Getting dressed in record time, I asked, "Who shall I say is asking?"

"Brad Williams," Sam said.

All eyes turned to her, which let us finish getting dressed, at least.

"Long time no see," Sam said. Caressing her belly, she said, "There have been a couple of developments since I saw you last. Which would you like me to catch you up on first?"

"Brad, what is she talking about?" asked the girl.

"Nothing, Andrea, nothing," Brad replied.

"How about this," Sam offered. "You catch me up, and then I'll catch you up. So, Brad: How's that cancer coming?"

"Cancer?" asked the girl. "Brad, what did you do?"

"He told me he wouldn't be going to school anymore," Sam explained, "because he was dying of cancer, that's what he did. Who are you?"

"I'm Andrea, his sister, his ride, and the one who gets to tell Mom and Dad all about this. May I ask, were you so... ?"

"No, I wasn't a giantess yet. I started growing after Brad got me pregnant."

"What's going on here?" Dad asked. "Who are these people?"

"Dad," I said, "these are Andrea and Brad Williams. You may remember his name coming up a while back."

"Oh, yes," Dad said. "You were the one who tricked my daughter. Telling her you were dying to get your hands on her body. If you hadn't moved to New York, I might have made that lie into the truth."

Brad chuckled nervously. "Guess I was lucky."

"The day isn't over yet," Dad observed.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: My 18th Birthday

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Andrea called her parents, and they came over. I'll give them credit, they quickly adjusted to the presence of giants, not to mention the 12-year-old girl with muscles on her muscles.

"So my son got your daughter pregnant," Mr. Williams said.

"That is correct," Dad replied.

"And you're certain he's the father?"

"Brad was the first, and, to date, only boy I've been with," Sam answered. "Unless he's got an identical twin brother who you left at home, there's nobody else."

"And I didn't invite you into my home," I added, "to listen to you level baseless allegations against my little sister."

"I'm sorry," he quickly said. "I meant no disrespect."

Mrs. Williams stepped in. "How many are you having, may I ask?"

"Just the one," Sam replied, rubbing her belly. "We come from a line of giants, and this baby won't be one of the small ones."

Andrea raised her hand. "May... may I...?"

Sam motioned for her to come closer, and put her hand on her belly.

Her eyes widened. "Whoa! Was that a kick?"

"That it was," Sam answered, still keeping her hand over Andrea's.

Our parents and Brad's parents talked it over, and reached an agreement. Suffice it to say, Sam's baby would be going to school until it outgrew the building.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Repercussions

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
A few days later, I decided to have another look at Mammoth Stadium. Stepping out onto the field, I spotted something on the ground. When I picked it up, I saw it was a wireless microphone. "How about that?" I said, then recoiled when I heard my voice coming over the sound system. Somebody left it on, I realized.

On a whim, I brought the mic to my lips and began to sing:

At first I was afraid, I was petrified
Kept thinking I could never live without you by my side
But then I spent so many nights thinking how you did me wrong
And I grew strong, and I learned how to get along

I was having a ball, and I sang the whole song. Once I got to the instrumental section, I even heard music.

What surprised me, though, was that, when the song was over, I heard applause.

Turning in the direction of the applause, I saw the marching band. "How long have you been there?" I asked.

"We've been practicing," a band member explained. "We heard you singing, so we decided to join in. You're a good singer."

I blushed. "Thanks. Can I ask you guys a favor?"

"What could you need from us?"

"I'm getting married here in a few weeks, and I need musicians."

"You're the lady from Search and Rescue, aren't you?"

"Guilty as charged."

"We'll be here, ma'am. Count on us."

As I left the stadium, I remembered them complimenting my singing voice. I didn't think I sounded too bad over the speakers, either. Maybe I could've been something in the entertainment industry, if I weren't so big that nobody needed to buy a ticket to see me.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: My Impromptu Singing Debut

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
I got the invitation to a bridal shower, only, to my surprise, it was not at my house. It was to be held in an isolated valley, the southern side of which was only viewable from Old Town Road. This was a place cut off to all most of the year, due to its being a treasured national monument known as Chapel Mountain. It was called this because of the tiny church one minister had built at the top, with an insane view of the northern end.

"Allison Hayes had to have something to do with this." Smiling slightly, I muttered.

I walked out to the valley, where I met Grandma waiting for me at the impressively large entrance to Faith Cave in Chapel Mountain. It was over a hundred feet tall and thirty feet wide, making it easy for me to enter. "No one is allowed in here during the winter season, as ice sheets from the mountain have been known to seal the entrance until spring thaw." Serious, she said. "Only, because it is summer, we were given permission to hold the bridal shower here."

"I've never been in here." Curious, I said. "What makes this place so..." Then I saw what was inside the cave and, with a shaking voice, finished, "... special..."

Faith Cave was a huge crystal cave that looked much like the inside of an ice castle straight out of a fantasy novel. The light from the entrance and various tunnels leading to the outside made the air inside sparkle like magic. "This is where your grandfather proposed to me." Smiling, Grandma said. "How could I say no?"

With that, the bridal shower began with fun games, mostly aimed at poking fun of boys in general, as well as celebrating our lives as independent women and girls. Of course, we had to keep it kid-friendly due to Ashley and Joey, but that did not stop Aunt Marge from throwing in a joke that was over the kids' heads.

"I wonder how Jason will handle the exotic dancers I hired for his bachelor party?" Teasing, she stated. She giggled when I turned to her, startled. "Just kidding."

We all laughed at that, though Ashley and Joey were fortunately confused. "What's exotic mean...?" Ashley asked.

We all laughed harder and replied, in unison, "Never mind."

Next came the gifts. Mom got me a number of 'big baby' blankets, booties, baby bottles, etc in both blue and pink. Seeing my questioning look, Mom smiled. "It's a mother's dream, dear." Softly, she said. She then winked. "It's also a mother's revenge, as I get to spoil them."

Grandma giggled. "I know this from experience."

I blushed at that as Holly, Melodie, and Cathy approached me with a gift from the three of them and it took the three of them to lift it. "We know the owner of the local candy store, and gave him a challenge." Grinning, Cathy said.

"We hope you like it." Smiling, Holly said.

"You didn't have to go through all that trouble..." Tearing up, I said.

I opened the gift and let out a low gasp before tearing up... It was all of my favorite chocolates... in my size! I chose one and popped it into my mouth. It was like a piece of heaven to my taste buds. "It's delicious!" Cooing, I chirped. "Thank you!"

Holly and Melodie giggled, happy that I loved their present. Cathy smiled. "They could think of no better present than something you miss."

Next was Grandma, who gave me the recipe for the ointment, and a beautiful multi-symbol necklace. "Our family is ancient and has many religions." Calmly, she explained. "When a giant woman gets married, she gets one of these necklaces to wear on her wedding day, to remind her, us all, our family knows no bounds, and that includes religion."

"Thank you, Grandma." Tearing up, I said. "I love it."

Next was Allison Hayes, who gave me a huge patchwork crochet blanket. "There are a lot of mothers in this town who owe you their sons' and daughters' lives because of your gallant work." Serious, she said. "I started knitting this blanket, not knowing how I was going to get it done in time, when they came over and began to help with it."

"I love it." Tearfully, I said. "Thank you, and thank the ladies of the town."

Sam and Becca went together and got me a number of stuffed animals for my bedroom. "In case you miss your old ones." Smiling, Becca said.

"We made them with Aunt Marge's help." also smiling, Sam added.

"Speaking of which, I believe it's my turn." grinning, Aunt Marge said. She pushed a huge oak chest in my direction, with a heart-shaped lock on the lid. Marge smiled more as she handed me the key.

"What's in there?"

Marge giggled. "Open it."

Sighing, I unlocked the chest and opened it, only to blush profusely. It was filled with sexy lingerie, love toys, wrapped plates with hearts on them, and other intimate items. i closed the lid, then turned to Marge, who laughed.

"You never know when that will come in handy."

I could not help laugh myself. "Subtlety is definitely not your strong point."

The shower carried on well into the night.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: A Giant Bridal Shower

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"Another downside to being so big," I noted as the shower broke up, "it's going to take me a while to carry all this stuff home."

"You don't have to worry about that," Aunt Marge assured me. "I've arranged for my brothers to come help you."

"What did you mean by 'another downside'?" Mom asked.

"I found a live microphone at Mammoth Stadium," I replied, "and I did a little singing. The marching band was there, practicing, and they said I was good. Sure, singing is fun, and I like it, but who would pay to see someone sing when she's so tall that you can see her for free?"

Mom wrapped her arm around my ankle. "Maybe that's for the best," she said. "I know you can sing, but I've seen the way your face lights up when you tell me about saving someone's life, and I know which one you'd rather be doing."

"I guess you're right," I said, thinking of the big patchwork quilt I'd received. It would be comfortable, but what would really keep me warm was thinking about the kids I'd talked out of throwing it all away, and the ones who only lost their cars.

As Aunt Marge promised, my uncles came to help me carry my presents home. As we made our way to Old Town Road, I saw Sam sitting on a rock, with Andrea standing next to her, both taking in the view.

Then I saw them kiss, and I knew that we should give them some privacy.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: After the shower.

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"Hi, how are you?" I asked the young girl standing above me.

"Uhhh... "was her reply.

"I don't usually have to look up to talk to someone," I said. "Would you like it if we kept on like this, or should I climb up there with you?"

She stepped back, so I climbed up. As I reached the cliff, I saw that the girl was wearing clothes that were too small for her. "So," I asked, "want to talk about it? I usually hear how I wouldn't understand what someone's going through. What do you think? Want to try it anyway?"

She looked at her arms and legs. "I don't know if I can take this."

"It's usually scary at first. Now, I was a short girl, so it seemed like a dream come true, at first. But, when I just kept growing, that's when it got scary. But I had family with me." I gave her clothes a looking over. "I guess you don't?"

She shook her head. "Nobody's seen this in my family before."

"I see. Well, we've seen it a lot in my family. Got a pen and paper?"

She did. I sent her to Dr. Bunyan's office, then I gave her Grandma and Grandpa's number. "Those folks will be glad to talk you through this part of your life. Oh, yeah." I gave her the recipe for the ointment. "This will take care of your growing pains. I swear by it."

"Thanks. I, uh, was kind of hoping you would be here."

"I see. Well, how about spreading the word that you don't need to be so dramatic, you can just ask me on safer ground. By the way, what's your name? I want to let them know you'll be calling."

"Trish. Trish St. Pierre."

"Good to know you, Trish St. Pierre."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Back at Work

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
I had a bad case of pre-wedding jitters. About a hundred times a day, for a week, I called my family to ask if I should call it off. And, every time, they promised me that I would still want to marry Jason once I got through this.

And they weren't the only positive reinforcement I got. In the days before, the postal service had to send more than one letter carrier to deliver the well wishes I got from people whose names I didn't always recognize, but who I'd saved at one time or another. They usually included updates on how they were doing since I showed up in their lives, from ultrasounds to gallery showings. There were also well wishes put on the chain link fence around the airfield. I spent the nights before my wedding crying myself to sleep with tears of joy.

Finally, the big day (couldn't resist, sorry/not sorry) arrived. My gown may have been shorter than the average wedding dress, but it was positively demure compared to my usual attire of a strapless two-piece. Jason was well turned out, too, and I was glad I listened to my family instead of my nerves.

Mammoth Stadium was built to hold thousands, but it wasn't enough for all the people who showed up. It seemed like half the city was there for my special day. The mayor took the opportunity to give me the key to the city that I had politely declined on so many occasions. Ah, well, add it to the wedding gifts. I was glad to see Trish was there, and that she had found clothes that would fit her, at least for today.

The marching band struck up "Here Comes The Bride", and I carried Dad down the aisle. Well, he insisted that he'd dreamed of giving me away at my wedding since the day I was born, and this was the only way we could do it.

The minister was lifted skyward on a cherry-picker, so we could all look each other in the eye. The Jumbotrons showed everyone a first-class view of the proceedings. And the crowd went wild when the minister said, "You may kiss the bride."

We had to call on more than one caterer, but we got everybody, even all the giants in both our families, fed.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: The Big Day

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"What's that you've got there, Mrs. Finnegan?" Jason asked me, as we left the reception.

"A set of directions Grandpa gave me, Mr. Finnegan," I replied. "He said it would be the perfect place."

"Interesting," he said, and produced a sheet of paper of his own. "My parents told me this would lead us to the perfect place."

We compared. They were the same directions. "What do you think of that?" my new husband asked.

"Either two sets of in-laws have teamed up to put one over on the happy couple," I answered, "or this will lead us to the perfect honeymoon spot for giants."

Jason smiled, and I fell in love with him all over again. "If it's the perfect place, then we should definitely go there. On the other hand, if they went to this much trouble for a joke, then they deserve to have their laugh."

"My sentiments exactly. Let's get some clothes and be on our way."

******************************


The directions took us out of California into Colorado, up into the Rocky Mountains. Our route took us far off the road, and a map said there wouldn't be another paved road for a day's walk for a normal-sized person. "Well," I said, "we should find out soon if this is a trick or a... "

I never finished my sentence.

It was no trick. It was a glorious valley, perfectly sized for giants. A 30-foot man in a ranger's outfit waved to us. "Welcome to Colossal Valley," he said. "What brings you here?"

"We're on our honeymoon," I replied.

The ranger nodded. "In that case, you'll be wanting the bridal suite. Follow me."

He led us to a magnificent cabin, almost as big as my house. Inside, it was sumptuously appointed. "As we were promised," Jason said, "it's the perfect place. Thank you, sir."

Once we had freshened up and put some of our things away, Jason gave a sigh of satisfaction. "We couldn't ask for a better bed and breakfast," he said. "What do you want to do first?"

I opened the trunk Aunt Marge gave me. "How about we skip breakfast?"
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: The Honeymoon

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
We soon learned that Colossal Valley was quite popular with newlywed giants. The other couples were friendly, and didn't mind that Jason and I couldn't keep our hands (or any other body parts) off of each other. "Having fun?" one woman asked.

"It's what we came for," I replied. "Sex for breakfast, sex for lunch, sex for tea, and sex for supper."

"Sounds like quite the diet," her husband said.

"We call it The F Plan," Jason quipped.

When we weren't either eating or indulging our other appetites, we learned that Colossal Valley was once an ore mine that got used up sooner than they expected. They abandoned it and forgot all about it, leaving one of their big trucks behind. One of the favorite activities was seeing how far you could pull the ore truck. Another was mountain climbing, which was quite difficult for giant lungs. There was also tug-of-war over the river (I'm afraid we lost more of those than we won).

As night fell, we swapped stories with the other couples. If this had been a competition, I would have won, as my stories from Search and Rescue had them hanging on every word.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Other Activities

choices: The Family, and a Surprise Guest
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
A honeymoon in a valley set aside for giants is a lovely thing, but the time came when we had to return home. We swapped addresses with our fellow honeymooners, with the intention of writing to keep each other updated on events in our lives.

When we got back home, there was a little welcoming committee waiting for us, as Ashley and Joey missed us too much to wait until we had settled back in before coming to see us. "Did you have fun?" they both asked. "What did you do?"

"We had a marvelous time," I replied. "We met other giants who were on their honeymoons, and we told stories, and played lots of games. But, mostly, we just enjoyed the fact that we were husband and wife." Which was as close as I was going to come to telling a couple of first-graders about sex.

"Can we go see where you went?" Joey asked.

"Not yet, Joey," Jason answered. "Colossal Valley is for giants."

The two kids played on the playground for a while, then they finally agreed with their mothers that it was time to go home.

"They're great kids," I said to Jason, after they left. "Maybe we can have some children of our own, someday."

"Yeah, maybe someday," Jason replied. "For now, though, you and I are enough."

We had a welcome-home supper, then some welcome-home sex, and then we fell asleep in each other's arms.

Little did we know that "someday" was on its way...
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Returning Home

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
My family visited every weekend, so it wasn't a surprise when they came to see us. What was a surprise, and a pleasant one, was who came with them.

"Trish! Great to see you!" I picked her up and hugged her. "What brings you out here?"

"A couple of things," she replied. "I outgrew my parents' house, and your grandparents insisted I stay with them, at least for a while."

"For a while, huh,? Well, don't ever forget how lucky you are. When it comes to how much love you've got, Grandpa is the biggest giant the world has ever seen. What's the second reason?"

"We're looking at hangars," she explained, "and getting inspiration from your house. Your grandpa's sure that I'll be a big one."

Over a meal, I learned more about Trish St. Pierre than she was able to tell me when we met. "I thought I was the only one in my family," she said, "but Dr. Bunyan helped me find a 7-footer on my mother's side of the family, and a strong woman on my father's side. They were just so far back that nobody remembered them."

"That can happen. So, what was your trigger?"

"Trigger?"

"What activated those dormant giant genes, Trish?"

She looked down and blushed. "I... had a bit of a crush on somebody, but they didn't even know I was alive."

"Well, how about now?"

"They know, but they're with someone else, and it feels like the real thing."

"I'm sorry it didn't work out the way you'd hoped it would," I said. "But it's a big world, with plenty of people in it. You're not the first giant to get her heart broken, and you won't be the last. Once you top out, I'm sure you'll have no trouble finding the right one for you. That's how I met Jason, after all."

"Thanks," Trish said. "That means more for me than you know."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: The Family, and a Surprise Guest

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"So," Dr. Bunyan asked, "what brings you in to see me, Summer?"

I had been married for about a month, and I had noticed a laundry list of things about me that were different. I decided to start with the simple one first. "I'm constantly stuffed up," I said. "I've had this for a week, with no change."

"I see," he said. He took a look up my nose. "Have you experienced anything other than stuffy nose?"

I opened my mouth to speak, but a rather loud belch came out instead (and I'm 50 feet tall, so factor that in). I covered my mouth. "Sorry," I said, "that just came out."

"Do you get a lot of that?"

"The sad part is, that's not the most embarrassing noise to come out of my body. I've been known to shake the trees recently. Sometimes, I try to blame it on someone else, but I'm sure nobody believes it."

"I see. Is there anything else?"

"My, uh, sex drive has taken a tumble lately. I've gone from barely being able to keep my hands off of Jason to not wanting him to touch me sometimes."

"I see. Anything else?"

"Lately, I've been feeling... underdressed."

"Well, there are a few things that might cause these symptoms. I'd like to do a simple blood test, if I could."

I agreed to the test, and Dr. Bunyan took a sample of my blood. Thanks to my being so big, he didn't need to take much, proportionately speaking.

An hour later, he returned. "Do you know what it is?" I asked.

"It's one of two things," he replied. "A boy or a girl."

I wasn't sure if I heard him right. "Huh?"

"You're pregnant."

At this announcement, I fainted.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Curious Symptoms

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
When I came to, Dr. Bunyan was smiling down at me. "Congratulations," he said.

"Pregnant? Me? Are you sure?" What can I say? I was slow on the uptake.

"I ran the test twice," he answered. "Both came back positive. I'm sure."

"I'm pregnant," I said, still processing it. "I can't believe it. I haven't thrown up once."

"Giantesses don't get morning sickness, Summer. You know this."

Now I remembered Grandpa saying that when we found out Sam was pregnant. Like I said, slow.

"As for your other symptoms," he continued, "most of them are quite common among women of all sizes, including fainting and fuzzy thinking. The desire to cover up more is mainly found in bigger women like yourself."

I felt better, knowing that what I was feeling was all just part of pregnancy, including my sudden slowness. "Thank you so much, Doctor. Now, how do I tell Jason the good news?"

"That's entirely up to you. I'll refer you to an OB/GYN for the rest of your pregnancy. She'll contact you for your first appointment. Goodbye."

"Goodbye, Doctor."

******************************


I decided to break the news to Jason slowly, starting with fixing his favorite meal for supper. He was thrilled when he came home and that familiar aroma greeted him. "You didn't," he said.

"I did."

"Oh, honey, you shouldn't have."

"I should have."

Halfway through the meal, I asked, "How was your day?"

"I got the job. I'm a forest ranger now."

"Oh, honey, congratulations." I ran around the table and kissed him. "You've been looking forward to this for so long."

"So, uh, how do you think we should celebrate? Or is this it?"

"I saw Dr. Bunyan today."

"Oh? What did he say?"

"He said I'm pregnant."

He stopped eating. "Pregnant?"

I nodded. "That's why I've been stuffed up, why I have such terrible gas, why it seems like I'm in a perpetual fog,... and why I've lost interest in... you know."

Now it was Jason's turn to run around the table. When he did, he picked me up and kissed me. "How was that?"

"I could get used to it. Too bad I'll be too heavy for it in a few months."

He gently set me down. "I've got to tell my folks."

"Oh, honey, can we not? I'd like to keep this our little secret for a while."

"How long?"

"Until I'm three months along."

He sighed. "I guess I can do that. Our little secret." He put his hand on my belly, even though it was perfectly flat. "Should we be hoping for a boy or a girl?"

"Let's just hope it's happy and healthy, and worry about the rest later."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Continue

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
When Ashley and Joey came to visit, their mothers commented that I was in a good mood, but didn't speculate as to why. When my family came, it was another story.

Before it came to that, I was surprised to see Andrea joining us. "Your folks took me in," she explained, "after my family kicked me out. My brother blabbed that I had a thing for Sam, because he was afraid she would hurt me, being so big. But my folks gave me the boot because Sam isn't short for Samuel."

"I'm sorry your parents feel that way," I told her, "but you're welcome in our home."

A few minutes later, I was fixing supper, when Grandma and Grandpa came up to me. "So when were you planning to tell us?" Grandma asked.

"I don't know what you're talking about," I replied.

"Summer," Grandpa said, "I've been around giants my whole life. Did you honestly believe that I wouldn't notice the signs that a giantess is going to have a baby?"

I felt deflated, and Jason put his arm around me. "I wanted it to be a secret," I said, "just for a little while."

"I'm sorry, dear," Grandma said, "but there's just one reason a giantess goes from a two-piece strapless number to a dress that covers her to her knees. How are you two doing?"

"We're happy about the baby," I replied, "but I miss being... interested. You know?"

"I know. I'm afraid I don't have an ointment for it, but I can tell you those feelings will return in a few weeks."

I sighed with relief. "I was a little worried. Thank you both." I turned to Jason and shrugged.

As I put the food on the tables, I cleared my throat. "I had originally planned to keep this a secret for a couple of months," I said, "but I guess it's a little more obvious than I thought. Jason and I... Jason and I are having a baby."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Keeping a Secret Is Hard

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Dad's reaction to my announcement was, I guess, fairly predictable. "Already? Summer, the two of you have only been married a month, and you're already starting a family? What in the world - ?"

And he probably would have gone on like that, if Mom hadn't pulled him to her side and whispered something to him. I couldn't catch the whole thing, but the words "barn door" and " horses" came up.

When she finished, Dad cleared his throat. "I guess what I meant to ask," he said, "was, Are you sure you're ready? It doesn't sound like the best example of family planning."

"Well," I replied, "you might have a point, Dad. This wasn't really planned or unplanned. We had started talking about maybe having children someday, unaware that I had already conceived. But it's not the worst example. Is it?"

"I... I suppose not," Dad said, subtly reminded of how many months there were between my parents' anniversary and my birthday.

"Well, congratulations, Summer," Sam said. "I'm sure our kids will have lots of fun playing together."

"Cool," Becca said, "a second babysitting gig."

"I won't mind being an alternate," Trish said, "if either of you need me."

"All your offers are deeply appreciated," I said. Turning to Trish, I asked, "Have you given any thought to what you'll do once you're out on your own?"

"Not yet, I hadn't," she replied. "Do you think I should?"

"Well, if you're interested, I could recommend you for Search and Rescue. Maybe even train you. After all, they won't want me to handle too many risky jobs, once I tell them what condition I'm in."

"Sounds good to me. When do I start?"

"Well, first, I have to clear it with my higher-ups. But I don't foresee a problem. I'll call you with details afterwards."

And, with that, the meal became more genial, more festive. Finally, Mom and Dad offered me their congratulations on my upcoming bundle of joy.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Reactions

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
On Monday, before I headed off to Old Town Road, I called my superiors at Search and Rescue. "Good to hear from you, Summer," my boss said. "How's married life treating you?"

"Surprises all the time," I replied. Maybe I couldn't keep my pregnancy a secret from my family, but Search and Rescue wouldn't hear about it until I was ready to tell them. "But I'm calling about something else. There's a growing girl I know, and I'd like to train her for the job."

"Another one? How big is she?"

"She's under 15 feet, but we're all sure she'll get bigger. She's going to be my neighbor, here on the airfield."

"Well, for the record, give me a week to think it over. Off the record, if you think she'll do good work, that's good enough for me. But don't tell her it's a shoo-in. Just tell her she'll get an interview."

"Thank you, ma'am. You won't regret this."

When the call was over, I called Trish and told her to be ready next week. Then, I went to my post.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Getting Trish a Job

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Trish was 15 feet tall when she officially became my trainee. We sat together at Old Town Road, waiting for whatever happened. "Can I let you in on a secret?" she asked.

"Absolutely," I replied.

"Remember when I said I had a crush on somebody, and that was what started me growing?"

"I do."

"It was you."

"Me?!"

"I know, you hear it from everybody - "

"No, I really don't. In fact, counting you, I've had only two people tell me they were attracted to me."

We probably would have gone on with that conversation, but we were interrupted by a woman's echoing scream. "Who was that?" Trish asked.

"I don't know," I replied, "but I think it came from Chapel Mountain, maybe Faith Cave." I took off for the cave, careful not to knock over any trees.

When I got to the cave, I was surprised to see Trish was already there, her arm around a 12-foot-tall girl. "How'd you get here so fast?"

"I know a shortcut. Emphasis on short, I'm afraid: I don't think I'll be able to use it after my next growth spurt."

"Speaking of growth spurts," I said, hunkering down, "I take it that's what happened to you?"

She nodded. "My name's Joy. They all kicked me out when I started growing like this."

"Well, I know some people who won't kick you out," Trish said.

"They probably wouldn't," I said, "but it's not fair to my grandparents to ask them to take in every giant with nowhere else to go. We'll take her to my place." Turning to Joy, I asked, "Do you think you can walk it?"

She shook her head, so I carried her.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Another Growing Girl

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Upon returning home, I gently put Joy in a chair, while Trish grabbed a blanket before wrapping her in it. Joy sighed with a touch of relief as she slouched down into the blanket's warmth, a slight grin touching the corners of her mouth. "Thank you."

"You are welcome." Smiling back, Trish replied.

I radioed Search and Rescue, and informed them that I was helping a lost giantess, then requested that Dr. Paul Bunyan meet me at my house, as the local hospital was not equipped to handle giants. "Your shift is almost over anyway." Kindly, Allison radioed back. "We'll get ahold of Paul and Jason for you."

"You're the best, Allison." I radioed. "Summer out." I turned to Trish. "Do you think you can watch over her while I get us some drinks and snacks?"

Trish nodded, blushing slightly. I hid a grin seeing Joy blushing slightly as well, and entered the kitchen. I could not help but grin as I grabbed some water and ginger snaps, knowing the look Trish and Joy gave each other all too well. "A crush at first sight..." Bemused, I muttered. "First day in Search and Rescue, and she already found a fan."

I giggled to myself as I brought them in, to find Dr. Paul Bunyan and Jason enter with worried expressions. "I heard you have a lost giantess." Calmly, Paul said. "What have you found so far?"

"She's near exhaustion, doctor." Worried, Trish said. "She's also very cold."

"Let's have a look, then." Approaching, Paul said. "Care to tell us your story?"

"My name is Joy Gaia." Softly, she said. "I lived in Lake Valley, Nevada. I started growing shortly after the fist full moon of the year."

"How tall were you before you started growing?" Calmly, Paul asked.

"Less than five foot." Wincing, Joy replied. "I was being called all kinds of short names from just about everyone."

"That sounds familiar." Softly, Trish said.

"I take it your townsfolk did not take your growth spurts well." softly, Paul said.

Joy teared up. "They're all a superstitious lot. My growth spurts were seen as a bad omen because of the full moon connection, and demanded I leave town..."

"What of your parents?" worried, Jason asked.

Joy cried. "They- they kicked me out..."

At this point, Trish was freely crying as Paul finished his examination. "Well, you need not worry about any of that nonsense here." Firmly, he said. "As you can see, giants are welcome in this valley."

We all nodded, bringing hope to Joy's eyes. "How bad is she, doc?" Worried, Trish asked. "Will she be okay?"

"It's nothing serious." Calmly, Paul replied. "Slight dehydration, mild hypothermia, likely from climbing the mountain pass, and light exhaustion."

"It's her heart and soul I'm worried about." Wincing, Trish said. "To be kicked out of her own home... her own town..."

"That won't happen here." Serious, Jason said. "Your house is now move-in ready. Summer's family set it up, just as they did her house."

Trish smiled and turned to Joy. "Then you can live with me."

Joy's eyes widened, filled with hope. "Really...?!"

Trish nodded, and Joy wrapped her arms around her, crying. It was a touching moment for everyone, but Paul gently pulled them apart. "You need to rehydrate yourself, young lady." Firmly but kindly, he ordered. "Drink."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Joy

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Trish went back to Grandma and Grandpa's for her things, and I went to the kitchen. "This place is so big," Joy said. "Am I going to be as big as you?"

"All giants are different," I replied. "The first giantess I ever met is 7 feet tall. My grandfather is about as tall as you are now."

"My mom is twice Summer's size," Jason added.

"Great," she said. "So, even among freaks, I could be a freak."

"None of us are freaks, Joy," Dr. Bunyan told her. "All of us are different. There is no one way for everyone to be."

"Jason," I asked, "could you get the phone in the bedroom and hit 5 and 6 for speed-dial? I've got a housewarming gift to whip up."

"What are you making?" Joy asked.

"It's a special ointment we giants swear by. With it, you won't feel any pain from your growth spurts. But, unlike other pain meds, this won't make you loopy, or give you nightmares."

Trish returned, and we all helped her and Joy get settled in. If the sparks they were giving off were more than metaphorical, they would have burned the place down.

"A couple of things I want to tell you," I said to Trish. "First, your first visitors will be Ashley and Joey. Joy's a little insecure about her growth, and the fastest antidote I can think of for that is two kids who love giants."

"I'm inclined to agree. What's the other thing?"

"Before your relationship gets physical, wait and make sure she's using the ointment. You see, exertion can cause a growth spurt, and so can orgasm."

"Oh. Oh! Oh."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Joy moves in with Trish.

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
A few days later, I was heading out for work. I was about to knock on Trish's door, when I spotted a car at the front gate.

Trish and Joy both stepped outside. "So you know," I said, "somebody's at the gate."

"We know," Joy replied. "Kyle at the gate told us. It's my parents."

"Alright," I said. "You two take the lead. I'll provide backup." And so the three of us went to see what Joy's parents wanted.

Trish stepped up first. "How do you do?" she asked. "My name's Trish. Joy and I live together. This is our neighbor, Summer."

"Hi," I said, waving.

"Joy," her father said, "we came to apologize. If we had seen any other way... "

"Like, maybe, protecting her?" Trish asked sarcastically.

"Do you think we didn't want to?" Joy's mother asked. "For God's sake, we couldn't protect her from three boys. How could we protect her from an entire town?"

"It's true," Joy said. "Right before I started growing, three boys thought it would be funny if they dumped me headfirst into a huge pile of fertilizer. Well, they thought it was funny. For days, they made jokes about how I smelled, up until I gave them something else to talk about."

"Sounds like that was your trigger," I said. "Well, you're a big girl now, Joy. How you deal with this is up to you."

Joy didn't say anything. She just opened the gate, got down on her knees, and hugged her parents.

"What do I do," Trish asked me, "if they want to take her home?"

"You don't have to worry," I told her. "Joy is home."

"You're right. Well, I guess my folks will have company on the second floor."

"I guess. Well, let's be off."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Joy's Parents

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
The next two months went by almost too quickly. Trish topped out at 40 feet tall, while Joy showed no signs of stopping yet. However, Ashley and Joey's love of giants had turned Joy's mood around, and she was now looking forward to growing.

Speaking of growing, I was now in the market for dresses that offered a skosh more room in the waist. I wasn't ready for maternity wear just yet, but it wouldn't be long now. So I figured I'd better tell my higher-ups about what was in store for me.

"Good to see you again, Summer," Allison said. "What brings you by?"

"I figured I'd rather you hear this from me," I said, "before it gets too big to ignore: I'm going to have a baby."

"A baby!" Allison got up and ran to the window. "If we were the same size, girlfriend, you'd be getting such a hug right now."

"I know! It's been killing me to keep this a secret this long. My family guessed it a couple of months ago, but they have more experience with pregnant giantesses."

"I'm happy for you, Summer, I really am. Unfortunately,... "

I nodded. "I knew this was coming."

She nodded. "Unfortunately, we can't have a woman in your condition doing risky things like climbing the cliff off of Old Town Road. I'm afraid I have to put you on maternity leave."

I nodded. "Well, at least I got Trish trained before I got sidelined, so people will be in good hands. Take care, Allison."

"You, too, Summer. Your post will be waiting for you when you come back."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Personal Growth

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
The next few days were frustratingly boring. I was jumping out of my skin, with nothing to do other than watch television and read books sent by my giant relatives. What made it worse was that I was having trouble making up my mind what I wanted to snack on when the cravings hit. I would literally spend minutes at a time, staring in the cupboards, refrigerator, and freezer, trying to decide. It came to the point where I was screaming and crying, due to not being able to make a decision.

Jason came home early on the seventh day of my maternity leave, to find me in the middle of one of these fits. "Honey!" running to me, he gasped. "What happened?!"

"I think I'm going insane!" Crying, I wailed. "I can't make up my mind what I was to snack on, and I am so hungry!"

Jason winced and called Grandma on speaker, who answered on the third ring. "Hey, Summer, how are you doing?"

"It's Jason, and Summer is in trouble." Worried, Jason said. "She can't decide what to eat, and, from what I understand, it has caused her not to eat all day."

Grandma giggled, surprising Jason. "Let me guess, she has the munchies, but is torn between one snack and another, no matter where she turns."

"That's it exactly." Crying, I said. "What is wrong with me?!"

"Nothing is wrong with you, sweetie." Cooing, she said. "Only you may want to look into purchasing two cribs..."

It took me a moment to get what Grandma was hinting at, but, when it hit, my jaw dropped before I teared up. "Twins?!"

Again, Grandma giggled. "Congratulations, honey!"

"How do we solve her craving issues?" Worried, Jason pressed.

"You worry too much, dear." Lightly, Grandma said. "When the cravings hit, take both choices before you, one for each baby."

In a strange way, it made sense. I moved to the refrigerator, loaded my hands with every snack that caught my eye, and took them to a chair to enjoy them. Watching me, Jason sighed, then turned to the phone. "Any other surprises I should know about?" Curious, he asked.

Grandma gave a chuckle. "They wouldn't be surprises if I told you."

I could not help giggle, hearing that. "You need to ask the right question to get the right answer, Jason."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Maternity Leave

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"Twins, huh?" asked Dr. Carruthers, my obstetrician. She was conducting the examination in my living room.

"That's what Grandma said," I answered. "When cravings hit, I want two things at once."

"It nearly drove Summer nuts," Jason added, "until we found out."

"Yep," she replied, "that does sound like twinsies. How about the three of us get an inside look? Lie down on the couch."

She stepped outside, and wheeled in a massive ultrasound machine. After smearing cold gel on my belly, she began listening for the babies' heartbeats. "There's one," she said, "loud and strong."

I listened, but I couldn't hear the second heartbeat. "I don't understand," I said. "Grandma's never steered me wrong before."

"Well," Dr. Carruthers said, "let's see if we can salvage Grandma's reputation, shall we?" She switched on the monitor, studied the image for some time, then turned it so we could see. "There we are."

I saw one baby,... but only one. "Grandma was so sure."

"Now, hold on," the doctor said, "let's not count the old girl out just yet. Look at this." She pointed at a spot on the monitor.

Jason and I looked at the spot for a full minute before it hit us. "Is... is that... ?"

"I take it one of you started small?"

"Both of us."

"Well, there we go," the doctor said. "One big, one small. And Grandma's record is intact. That's three pieces of good news in one visit, a personal record."

Our babies were different sizes. I never would have imagined it. But then, I wouldn't have imagined that one year would see me grow to ten times my original size, find my calling, fall in love, get married, and start a family of my own.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: More surprises.

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
I went to Trish and Joy's house, and Joy answered the door. "Look at you!" I said. "I swear, you get bigger every time I see you. Somebody learned what brings on growth spurts, huh?"

It was undeniable. Joy was maybe four feet shorter than I was, which didn't make much difference among giants. "What can I say? We love each other. And being big doesn't scare me anymore."

"Well, I came to invite you both to a party we're throwing at the airfield. We've got a big announcement to make."

"You do? Well, thanks for the heads-up. We'll be sure to be there."

******************************


The day of the party arrived, and everyone was there. My family was there, of course, as were Ashley and Joey and their parents. Jason's family was there, and they were dressed, if not fully. Even Allison made it.

"Now that everyone is here," I said, "it's time for our big announcement. Some of you may have guessed part of it, but I'm here to tell you the whole thing. Jason and I are having twins: one big, one small."

Even Grandma and Grandpa were surprised by that, which was a rarity.

"What do you mean," Ashley asked, "one big, one small?"

"It means one of the babies will be giant-sized," I explained, "and one will be no bigger than you were when you were born."

Everybody congratulated us, but what will stay with me is something that happened afterward: while everybody else was eating or playing, I saw Trish and Joy slip off to the side. I couldn't hear what they said, but I saw Trish on one knee, and Joy nodding and wiping her eyes.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: The Announcement

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
I had to look up when Joy came to my door. "What is that?" I asked. "Five feet?"

Joy nodded. "My growth has slowed up a bit. Also, getting my heart pumping won't trigger it anymore." She handed me an envelope. "It's our turn."

"We wouldn't dream of being anywhere else. Thanks."

******************************


Many of the same people came to Trish and Joy's get-together as to our baby announcement. Instead of Jason's relatives, Trish's and Joy's parents were there. They were well received, and they got along with each other famously. I knew what Trish and Joy were going to say, but their parents had a few words with them, and I had no idea what they said.

Whenever Trish and Joy were either with other guests or in private, Sam was the center of attention. After all, it wouldn't be long now before she welcomed her little bundle of joy into the world.

"Well," Trish finally said, "I can't keep this a secret any longer. Last week, I proposed to Joy. And she said yes!"

This was greeted with a standing ovation.

"The wedding will be at Faith Cave," Joy said, "where we first met. And, as if that wasn't special occasion enough, both sets of parents will renew their wedding vows, right then and there."

This brought on another standing ovation.

Then Sam stood up. "I hate like hell to upstage you guys," she said, "but my water just broke."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Trish and Joy's Announcement

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"Remain calm, all of you," Grandma said. "It is a birthing ritual among giants that the child be born with as little stress as possible." Turning to Sam, she asked, "Will one of the hangars be good?"

Sam nodded, and I carried her to a vacant hangar, moving slowly so as not to upset her. This also helped the crowd keep up with me. Meanwhile, Grandma called the midwife and gave her directions.

I found the cleanest spot I could, and gently set Sam down. "How are you feeling?" I asked.

Sam nodded. "I'm ready for this to be over. Andrea?"

"I'm right here," she replied. "You're doing well, my love."

It took half an hour for the midwife to get to the airfield, but she made it well before the baby did. Grandma sang softly as Sam labored.

Naturally, all of us were keenly interested in the process, most because it was the first giant birth we'd ever witnessed, Jason and I because we would be doing it ourselves in six months' time.

It struck me that Andrea, instead of holding Sam's hand, rubbed Sam's shoulders and planted kisses on her temples. I wondered if that was because of the size difference, or if it was simply how giants did it.

Sam was in labor through the rest of the day and into the night. Lamps were lit to assist the midwife.

Finally, well after dark, Sam gave birth to a baby boy. The baby was greeted with great rejoicing, and Andrea helped to cut the umbilical cord.

"You did an amazing job, sweetie," Mom said. "I couldn't have kept my cool as long as you did."

"There are two residences nearby," the midwife said to Sam. "Will one be good?"

"Good for what?" I asked.

"It's another giant birth tradition," Grandpa replied. "For three weeks, the new mother lives with family. She will stay in bed, bonding with her child, while her relatives tend to every need."

"Oh. Okay, Jason, open the door. I'll carry our VIP houseguests inside."

In no time at all, we had Sam settled into her usual bed in my home. "Have you picked out a name?" I asked.

"Matthew Joseph," Sam answered.

"Welcome to the world, Matthew Joseph Roberts."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Sam's Baby

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
"I hope we're not being a burden." Wincing, Sam said. "We have our own place."

"Nonsense." Smiling, I said. "You are family, we take care of each other."

Sam blushed at that. "Thank you."

After getting Sam and Andrea settled in, I began to walk to the kitchen to prepare breakfast, as it was nearly morning.

Only Jason placed a firm hand onto my shoulder. "Where do you think you are going, miss?" In a playful scolding tone, he demanded.

I turned to him to find a certain twinkle in his eye: he was up to something. "I think I am about to make us breakfast." Calmly, I replied.

Jason shook his head. "You are going to march into bed." Serious, he said. "I need to get used to this, for when it is my turn to tend to your every need."

I opened my mouth, but Jason silenced me with a single finger on my lips. "Andrea will help me, as I am tending to two, but I need this for when I have three to worry about."

I smiled at that: Jason was a true gentleman. Through mild protests, I allowed myself to be led to bed, and Jason tucked me in. "You know, I could get used to this." Smiling, I teased. "Don't spoil me too much."

Jason chuckled. "You'll be going nuts by the end of the first week." Grinning, he said. "You need this to be ready, too."

Andrea giggled. "He has a point." Smiling, she said. "Sam is likely already going crazy with cabin fever by now."
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Houseguests

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
I didn't make it a week. Maybe I was too used to taking care of myself. Maybe it was the wrongness of putting me on bed rest when there was a new mother in the house to tend to. Or maybe it was the cold, hard fact that Jason Finnegan was a bad cook. Whatever the case, I had to get back on my feet sooner rather than later.

Mom, Dad, and Becca had moved in to help tend to Sam, but they were having little success. "I don't care about traditions," she shouted, "I'm going stir crazy in here!"

She made it out the bedroom door, but not much farther. Luckily, I had a decent set of reflexes, and I caught her before she fell on her face. "I've got you, little sister," I said. "Let's get you back to bed."

As I put her in bed again, she said, "You understand me, right?"

I nodded. "You're used to doing things for yourself. But you just had a baby a few days ago. I suggest you use this time as a chance to get to know little Matt as more than just the one who made you go to the bathroom every five minutes. I've taken myself off bed rest, so I can start pulling my weight in this house again."

Jason touched my arm. "Honey, we discussed this."

I turned to him. "Dear husband, light of my life: I suggest you study cooking over the next six months. If I must leave my kitchen in your care, I want to know that it's in better hands than the ones that have been fixing my meals recently. Do I make my position clear?"

"Yes, dear."

"Good. Besides, there's something I almost missed, lying on my back all day, every day." I brought his hands to my abdomen. "I am officially rocking a baby bump." I gave him a kiss.
1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.title: Cabin fever.

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Grandma chuckled from behind, catching my attention. "You are going to wish you were in bed with nothing to do once your baby starts demanding attention and to be fed at all hours of the night." Bemused, she said. "All traditions have their reasons..."

"What are the reasons behind being stuck in bed for three weeks with my baby in the crib next to me?" Annoyed, Sam demanded.

"First, you learn more patience which is something you desperately need right now, young lady." Firmly, grandma explained. "Second, you bond with more than your baby, you bond with your life mate and other family members."

"Which makes us closer, right?" guessing, Becca asked.

"Much more than that, my dear." Patiently, grandma replied. "They also learn things about their life mate and family members that would normally take decades to come to light... this removes most all secrets and anything that would threaten their marriage is resolved early in a calm and controlled manner."

Sam and I both blushed at that. "I already learned that James needs to learn how to cook before it's my time." Softly, I said.

"Oh, you took a trial run?" Bemused, grandma asked. She giggled. "You were wise to do that... why do you think I do all the cooking at home? Though I love my husband with all my heart, he couldn't even boil water... it was carry out for three solid weeks."

Jason winced. "I better start studying the culinary arts..."

Again, grandma giggled. "Do not get me wrong, he ordered whatever I wanted and he certainly had the money to spend." Calmly, she said. She turned to Jason. "I'll have you turning leftovers into gourmet meals before it's Summer's turn."

"I feel like such a heel..." Tearing up, Sam said.

"Nonsense!" Smiling, grandma said. "I was screaming obscenities by the end of my first week, driving your poor mother insane in the crib." She giggled. "By the end of the third week, not even an earthquake would wake her until she had children of her own."

After a moment of thought, Sam giggled. "So it teaches the baby patience too."

Grandma nodded. "Exactly."

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
Grandma was a big help, as always. Her words, combined with that attack of wooziness, put Sam back in bed, kissing every inch of her baby son.

Then, she and Jason went to the kitchen. The results of their culinary collaboration were good enough that I agreed to give this trial run another shot. I even gave him a kiss when he brought me my snacks.

Then Joy dropped by. "Surprised to see me?" she asked.

"Surprised to see so much of you," I replied. Not only had Joy grown another five feet, but she had stopped wearing anything on top.

She laughed. "Surprised me, too. I've even taken up sunbathing. And I don't think I'll be wearing my bottoms much longer."

I nodded. "Jason's folks are usually naked."

"Anyway, what is everyone doing in bed? You guys aren't sick, are you?"

"Disgustingly healthy. Sam's in bed because it's a tradition for giant moms to spend a few weeks in bed with their new babies. I'm in bed because Jason wants to practice a few months in advance."

"I see. Well, Trish and I don't mind waiting for you two to get back on your feet. Have fun."

******************************


At the end of the day, Jason brought me more snacks. "You've definitely been paying attention to Grandma's lessons," I told him. "Now I've got three things to look forward to in six months."

"Glad to hear it," Jason said. "I'll just change into my pajamas, grab my pillow and blanket, and head off to the couch."

I grabbed his wrist. "Do you have to?"

A smile touched his lips. "Feeling more like your old self, Mrs. Finnegan?"

"Unless you had your heart set on the couch. Or your pajamas."

He got undressed. "Not nearly as much as I've been waiting for this."

1111111111111111111212111121111111111111.content:
That night, just before retiring for the evening, I got a call from Search and Rescue. Knowing it had to be important, I answered on the second ring. "Summer Roberts..."

"Summer, we have reports of another climber on Old Town Road." Worried, dispatch said. "We have rescue crews on the way, but we are hoping you can get there faster."

"I'm already there!" Running to the door, I replied.

Being fifty feet tall, running a mile to Old Town Road only took me a few minutes across country. Upon arriving, I saw a young girl falling from the road, screaming in terror. With my heart in my throat, I jumped forward and caught her just in the nick of time. The poor girl was crying, trembling... What happened to you? Feeling pity, I thought. Then I gently said, "Easy there, I have you. You are safe."

The girl nearly screamed looking at me... I guessed she had never seen a giant girl before only she screamed, "Help me! I can't..."

I jumped as the girl then screamed again in utter terror before vanishing from my hand. Startled, I looked around, searching for the girl as her horrified scream echoed into the distance. Not seeing anything, I shuddered and turned to the top of the cliff, where I spotted a young policewoman who had the same startled look I did.

"There are tales of ghosts reliving their last moments here on Old Town Road, Summer." Sadly, she said with a shrug. "You and I may have just witnessed one."

I shuddered at the thought, and returned home, feeling as if I had failed that young girl. "She felt so real in my hand..." Tearing up, I muttered. I then knotted my jaws in decision. "I am not losing anyone else on the job."

I again jumped as my cellphone rang again and I answered right away. "Summer Roberts... what is the emergency?"

"Easy, pumpkin." Gently, grandma said. "I apologize if I had startled you."

"It's okay, grandma..." With a sigh, I said. "I had a bit of a scare earlier... Tell you about it later. What's up?"

"Well, I pulled a few strings, and managed to book the perfect place for you and Jason to get married." She giggled. "It is where your great-uncles got married..."

"Don't keep me in suspense, Grandma." Lightly scolding, I said. "Where is this perfect place you booked for us?"

"The Garden Rose Stadium, home of my college alma mater, Mammoth University, home of the Valley City Goliath football team."

"A football stadium, Grandma... really?" Cracking a grin, I asked.

"Think about this, honey." Cooing, Grandma said. "The security will be tight, there will be plenty of places for friends and family to sit, the Jumbotrons will capture every moment, and you will have the best band in the valley playing 'Here Comes The Bride'."

I blushed at the image Grandma's descriptions gave me. "We- We'll think about it." Softly, I said.

"I'll be happy to give you a tour." Calmly, Grandma said. "Expect me at your house tomorrow morning... I know it's your day off. Good night, Summer."

With that, she ended the call. I sighed, then called Jason. "Jason... honey..."

"Summer?" Worried, Jason asked. "What's wrong?"

I teared up. "I need you..."

"I'm already there." Firmly, Jason said.
